question_text: A manufacturing company produces L-shaped metal brackets. The technical drawing shows the main rectangular section measuring 180mm × 100mm, with a smaller rectangular attachment measuring 80mm × 60mm. The attachment is positioned with a 40mm offset from the left edge of the main section. One corner of the main section has been chamfered at a 45° angle. What is the total perimeter of the outer edge of this L-shaped bracket (excluding the chamfered corner adjustment)?
visual_data: {"dimensions":{"width":500,"height":400},"visual_type":"measurement_diagram","visual_overview":"Complex measurement diagram with multiple dimensions and angles. Students work with technical specifications. Professional technical drawing - just precise measurements and object details. No engineering instruction.","detailed_description":"Draw L-shaped technical object on 500×400px canvas. Main rectangle 180×100px, attached rectangle 80×60px. Show all dimensions: main width 180mm, height 100mm, attachment width 80mm, height 60mm, offset 40mm from edge. Include angle measurement 45° for chamfered corner. Use professional technical drawing standards with dimension lines, extension lines, and precise labeling.","specific_elements":{"l_shaped_object":"Two connected rectangles forming L-shape","primary_dimensions":"Main rectangle 180×100mm with dimension lines","secondary_dimensions":"Attachment 80×60mm with positioning","offset_measurement":"40mm offset dimension from main edge","angle_dimension":"45° chamfer angle with arc notation","technical_notation":"Professional dimension line standards"},"constraints":["No technical drawing instruction","No engineering explanations","No measurement technique guidance","Just precise technical specifications","No calculation assistance","Professional drawing standards only"]}
solution: To find the perimeter of the L-shaped bracket, we need to trace around the outer edge. Starting from the bottom left and going clockwise: bottom edge of main section (180mm), right edge of main section (100mm), top edge from main to attachment (40mm), right edge of attachment (60mm), top edge of attachment (80mm), left edge of attachment (60mm), remaining top edge of main section (60mm), and left edge of main section (100mm). Total: 180 + 100 + 40 + 60 + 80 + 60 + 60 + 100 = 680mm.

question_text: A music streaming company analysed their regional subscription sales for this year compared to last year. Looking at the chart showing sales figures (in thousands), which region had the greatest percentage increase from last year to this year?
visual_data: {"dimensions":{"width":600,"height":400},"visual_type":"bar_chart","visual_overview":"Horizontal grouped bar chart showing regional sales comparison. Students compare current vs previous year data. Professional chart style - just grouped bars and essential labels. No analysis guidance or educational content.","detailed_description":"Draw horizontal grouped bar chart on 600×400px canvas. X-axis from (100,50) to (550,50), scale 0-600. Four regions at y=100,150,200,250. Each region has 2 bars: \"This Year\" (top, #1976d2) and \"Last Year\" (bottom, #64b5f6), 20px height each, 5px spacing. Bars: North 450/420, South 380/350, East 520/480, West 290/310. Value labels at bar ends. Legend at (450,320) showing color coding. Title \"Regional Sales Comparison\" centered.","specific_elements":{"x_axis":"Scale 0-600 with grid lines every 50px","grouped_bars":"2 bars per region, 20px height, 5px spacing","this_year_bars":"Blue (#1976d2), widths: 338,285,390,218px","last_year_bars":"Light blue (#64b5f6), widths: 315,263,360,233px","value_labels":"Numbers at end of each bar, Arial 12px","region_labels":"North, South, East, West on y-axis","chart_legend":"Color legend showing This Year/Last Year","chart_title":"\"Regional Sales Comparison\" centered"},"constraints":["No analysis instructions or guidance","No educational interpretation content","No calculation assistance","Just grouped bars with labels and legend","No trend analysis or explanations","Professional business chart style only"]}
solution: To find the greatest percentage increase, calculate the percentage change for each region: North: (450-420)/420 × 100 = 7.1%, South: (380-350)/350 × 100 = 8.6%, East: (520-480)/480 × 100 = 8.3%, West: (290-310)/310 × 100 = -6.5% (decrease). South has the highest percentage increase at 8.6%.

question_text: Study the numerical sequence diagram shown above. The top row displays a sequence of numbers, while the bottom row shows the differences between consecutive terms. Based on the pattern established in the first six positions, what are the two missing values that should appear in positions 7 and 8 of the top row?
visual_data: {"dimensions":{"width":700,"height":200},"visual_type":"pattern_sequence","visual_overview":"Complex numerical pattern sequence with multiple variables. Students analyze mathematical relationships. Technical sequence style - just numbers, positions, and precise formatting. No mathematical instruction.","detailed_description":"Draw numerical sequence on 700×200px canvas. Two rows: top row shows sequence 2,5,8,11,14,17,?,?, bottom row shows differences +3,+3,+3,+3,+3,?,?. Position numbers 1-8 below. Each number in 60×40px box, Arial 16px bold. Missing values shown as \"?\" in gray boxes. Clear alignment and consistent formatting.","specific_elements":{"number_sequence":"Top row: 2,5,8,11,14,17,?,? in individual boxes","difference_row":"Bottom row: +3,+3,+3,+3,+3,?,? showing increments","position_markers":"Numbers 1-8 below each column","missing_values":"Gray boxes with \"?\" for positions 7 and 8","box_formatting":"60×40px boxes, Arial 16px bold, consistent spacing","row_alignment":"Perfect vertical alignment between rows"},"constraints":["No mathematical analysis or explanation","No pattern rule explanations","No calculation guidance or steps","Just numerical sequence with formatting","No arithmetic instruction","Technical presentation only"]}
solution: The sequence follows a consistent arithmetic progression where each term increases by 3. Starting with 2, the pattern continues: 2+3=5, 5+3=8, 8+3=11, 11+3=14, 14+3=17, 17+3=20, 20+3=23. Therefore, positions 7 and 8 contain 20 and 23 respectively.
